summary.p: 2 fol. (bifolium); Shelfmark: EA1996.54; Writing surface: parchment, Qurʾānic Text: Q 3:55 and Q 3:57, Lines per page: 3, Dimensions: 380 x 120 mm, Script style: kūfī type D.I (see Déroche 1992: pp 44-45). The Folio belongs to a Qurʾān attributed to Amāǧūr, ʾAbbāsid governor of Damascus between 870-878. At least 251 folios from the same Qurʾān codex has survived in various collections around the world. 242 folios are preserved in Istanbul, in the Museum of Turkish and Islamic Art (TIEM) (See Déroche 1990). Déroche also mentions one folio in the Chester Beatty Library in Dublin, one in Cairo, one in Cambridge, and one possibly in Riyad. Alain George mentions that he was able to find three more folios in Damascus (Seee Alain George 2003).

On the recto pages of this fragment in the upper margin there is a waqf-note that reads: awqafahā ʾAmāǧūr - "Amāǧūr made it a waqf". Two waqfiyyas of this codex preserved in the Istanbul fragment TIEM ŞE 13.768/1 are dated 262/875-876. In one of the waqfiyyas is stated that the manuscript was made a "waqf in the city of Tyre" (modern Lebanon) (See Déroche 1990 PN: 59-60).
According to the entry of the collection http://jameelcentre.ashmolean.org/collection/921/object/10883 we find the following information:

"The bifolio presented here (Qur’an, 3:55&57), datable to the late 9th century, exemplifies the ‘monumental’ quality of the earliest written copies of this text. Distributed over three lines per page and executed in bold kufic, the verses are broken into syllables that regularly alternate with empty spaces, with red dots used to indicate vowels. While the result is a balanced and attractive layout, the lack of diacritical marks, which are used in Arabic to distinguish the single letters, and the inability to tell where a word ends and where another begins, makes the reading of the verses especially hard. Hence, scholars have suggested that Qur’ans with these features were meant to assist those who had already memorized the text with its recitation.These pages belong to a multi-volume Qur’an associated with Amajur (governor of Damascus between 869 and 877) that was donated as waqf or charitable gift to a mosque in Lebanon."
See also the website of the collection: https://collections.ashmolean.org/object/352047
